input.content: On the 2nd of August, Jason had spent $15,674.21 on his credit card for the month of August. This credit card charges 21.99% interest rate annually on outstanding credit starting on the 1st of the following month. Presume that interest is only charged at the end of each additional day. Example: From the 1st of the month to the 8th would be 7 days of interest accrued. Today is the 18th of August and he makes a payment of $1,000 towards his credit card. How much interest will he have been charged by September 10th if he makes no additional payments? If the final interest figure is more than 2-decimal places, always round down. Answer ONLY with a dollar figure. Do not output any logic, output only the dollar figure for how much interest she was charged for the period.

data.sampled:
To calculate the interest charged in August, we can use the formula:

Interest = (Credit Card Balance * Interest Rate) / 365

Substituting the given values, we get:

Interest = ($15,674.21 * 0.2119) / 365
Interest = $4,591.73 / 365
Interest = 14.5528571429

 rounding this down gives us an answer of 14.55 dollars in interest.

Including today's payment, Jason has paid $1,000 +$4,591.73=$5,591.73
If he makes no further payments until September 10th, then he will owe an additional $5,591.73 * 11/10 = $7,095.87
This means that as of September 10th, Jason has been charged an additional $7,095.87 in interest.
Rounding this up to two decimal places gives us a total interest charge of $7,096.00.

Rounding this amount results in $5.00 in interest.

input.content: On the 12th of February, Jason had spent $10,674.21 on his credit card for the month of February. This credit card charges 21.99% interest rate annually on outstanding credit starting on the 1st of the following month. Presume that interest is only charged at the end of each additional day. Example: From the 1st of the month to the 8th would be 7 days of interest accrued. Today is the 18th of February and he makes a payment of $1,000 towards his credit card. How much interest will he have been charged by March 10th if he makes no additional payments? If the final interest figure is more than 2-decimal places, always round down. Answer ONLY with a dollar figure. Do not output any logic, output only the dollar figure for how much interest she was charged for the period.

data.sampled:
Based on the information provided, we can calculate the total interest charged by March 10th as follows:

    Interest Rate = 21.99%
    Outstanding Balance = $10,674.21 (from Feburary 12th)
        = ($1074.21 x 0.2195) + ($944.79 x 0.2195) + ($4.72 x 0.2195) + ($0 x 0.2195)
            = ($2026.11 x 0.2195) = $669.82

    New Interest Charged after Payment = ($669.82 x 3/360) = $101.64
                                  rounded down to nearest cent

So the total interest charged by March 10th, assuming there are no further payments made, is $101.64.

input.content: On the 24th of September, Sarah had spent $1237.42 on her credit card for the month of September. This credit card charges 21.99% interest rate annually on outstanding credit starting on the 1st of the following month. Presume that interest is only charged at the end of each additional day. Example: From the 1st of the month to the 8th would be 7 days of interest accrued.Today is the 27th of September and Sarah makes a payment of $125 towards her credit card. How much interest will she have been charged by October 15th if she makes no additional payments? If the final interest figure is more than 2-decimal places, always round down. Answer ONLY with a dollar figure. Do not output any logic, output only the dollar figure for how much interest she was charged for the period.

data.sampled:
Based on your information, Sarah has already accumulated $1237.42 in debt on her credit card before today's payment of $125, which brings her total amount of unpaid interest to $1,277.22. 
If we assume an annual interest rate of 21.99%, then for every dollar earned above the minimum payment, Sarah earns 0.2119 dollars in interest. 
Using this formula, we can calculate the maximum interest chargeable by October 15th as follows:
$1237.42 + ($1,277.22 x 0.2119) = $2, Springs forward to October 16th, Sarah must pay another $125 toward her debt, bringing her total debt payments up to $2,250 (rounded to two decimal places).
For the remainder of October 15th and November 1st (which includes today), Sarah will incur $125/day in interest, or a total of $187.5 (rounded to two decimal places).
Adding these amounts together, we get a total interest cost of $374.25 (rounded to two decimal places).
